description: From Middle English bewepen, biwepen, from Old English bewēpan (“to weep over, mourn, bewail”), from Proto-West Germanic *biwōpijan (“to weep over”), equivalent to be- +‎ weep. Cognate with Old Frisian biwēpa (“to beweep”), Old Saxon biwōpian (“to beweep”).

verbs.description: beweep (third-person singular simple present beweeps, present participle beweeping, simple past and past participle bewept)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To weep over; weep for; weep about; deplore; lament.
examples: With Nymphs and shepheards yearly moane
In telling that my hart alone
Hath his last will in keeping.
